benchmark_details.name: MT-P REF (Metric-induced Translation PREFerence)
benchmark_details.overview: The dataset comprises 18k instances covering 18 language directions, using texts sourced from multiple domains post-2022. It leverages sentence-level quality assessments from professional linguists on translations generated by multiple high-quality MT systems to better align machine translation with human preferences.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To create a high-quality preference dataset for machine translation that better reflects human translation preferences by utilizing both automatic metrics and human evaluations.

data.source: Sentence-level quality assessments gathered from translations evaluated by professional linguists, relying on outputs from multiple high-quality MT models.
data.annotation: Annotations were performed by professional linguists evaluating translations on a continuous scale of quality.

methodology.calculation: Metrics were calculated based on the correlation of automatic evaluations with human assessments of translation quality.
methodology.interpretation: The results are interpreted based on the correlation of automatic metrics with human judgments, indicating the effectiveness of the translations.
methodology.baseline_results: Models aligned with the MT-P REF dataset significantly outperform baseline models on WMT23 and FLORES benchmarks, demonstrating improved translation quality.
methodology.validation: The dataset was validated through evaluations on competing translation models across different language pairs.

targeted_risks.harm: Risk of generating biased translations or reflecting socio-cultural biases inherent in training data.
